I think the answer is very complex; It really depends on what kind of career goals you have. Many people will tell you that GPA doesn't matter, and that a Berkeley CS degree will get you all sorts of good industry jobs in the Bay regardless of the grades you earned. If you're interested in software engineering and that's what you want to do then I would say go ahead and explore these harder classes since I found that this is generally true in this time and day.

I'll tell you how I view this kind of thing though personally. I like to try to keep my doors open for as long as possible. And while having a bad GPA won't even come close to ruining your life, the truth is that a good GPA is important for many pursuits. Not caring about your GPA closes your doors to many opportunities, namely graduate school programs. I assume that as a rising sophomore, you're still only getting an idea of what you want to do in your career. Hopefully you don't find that you want to pursue a master's or doctorate degree later in your undergraduate career and regret that you had a bad GPA. It is not foolish in my opinion to strategically choose classes to keep your GPA above water.

Hi, I'm a rising sophomore, intended CS, maybe declaring by next semester. So I've talked to some people who work in the field of CS and many of them say that math/stats-heavy concepts are actually very useful in their careers. 

I've personally been quite discouraged through the math portions of EE16A/16B. But I totally don't blame the professors, since I suspected my approach to learning math in high school is just incompatible with how math is taught in college. I'm not sure if this is the right place to ask, but does anyone here have a similar experience as mine, in the sense that you know math is not your "strong suit" but you decided to take those classes anyway for the knowledge even though you risked lowering your gpa significantly?

I was originally intending to just avoid as much math as possible in my time here at Berkeley, but I'm beginning to reconsider. I'm talking about those courses with a B- average :/ Does anyone know if taking a hard class (that isn't required for graduation) and getting a bad grade in it is "better" in terms of career advancement than not taking those classes at all if they have useful knowledge? I truly do have interest in those subjects, it's just that I'm worried that the results won't be great.
history.subject: Taking hard courses in stats/math for knowledge/"fun"?
